Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Emissions, Transport, and Health Impact Assessment of Black Carbon in China

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air pollution is an environmental and public heath issue that has the ability to shape quality of life and well being for large populations. In China in particular where the pace of development and population growth is outpacing implementation of environmental regulations, air quality is a growing concern. In cities, vehicles are a major source of ambient air pollution including particular matter, which includes by-products of fuel combustion. Particulate matter and especially PM2.5 (i.e., PM with diameter of 2.5 microns or smaller) are considered important indicators of health because in epidemiology studies, they have  been linked to increases in hospital admissions, asthma, heart and lung disease, and premature mortality.

Xi’an in central China is a rapidly growing city of approximately 8 million people. The goal of this project was to assess the exposure to particulate matter (PM) in three modes of transportation along a popular shopping route: 1) walking, 2) public bus and 3) passenger vehicle in Xi’an, China. Improved exposure assessment could identify areas for future research in reducing air pollution exposure or implementing controls. Research was supported by Dr. Junji Cao’s group at Chinese Academy of Science Institute of Earth Environment (IEECAS). Dr. Cao’s group has broad experience in air quality sampling and chemical analysis.

Morning and evening sampling during rush hours occurred over a week during July 2010 using three modes – walking, taxi, and public bus – along a 4.6km route that runs along a heavily trafficked road through residential and commercial neighborhoods. A DustTrack DRX was used to measure concentrations of PM and carried in a backpack with the inlet pointing outwards within the person’s breathing zone. Preliminary results suggest taking the bus in Xi’an along this particular route had the highest mean (geometric mean) concentrations (30ug/m3) of PM2.5 as compared to walking (25ug/m3) or taking a taxi (27ug/m3). Rain events were also observed to impact PM concentrations by reducing PM levels by approximately 40-56% during the days that rained and for the following 24 hours.

More sampling runs would be necessary to determine if these differences are statistically different from each mode but taking the bus may lead to higher exposure of traffic-related pollutants because the buses are in traffic near other vehicles and stop at bus stops which are hotspots for vehicular emissions. This project highlights the importance of including more detailed and personalized information in exposure assessments because how a person travels will impact his or her exposure to environmental hazards. Future research will be focused on creating a city-wide pollutant concentration layers for multiple pollutants using data from China EPA monitoring sites in Xi’an and collecting lifestyle and travel information from residents in order to improve exposure assessment and eventually, health impacts.
